com.mwdiamond.fansi

Class Ansi

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mwdiamond.fansi.Ansi

  • @CheckReturnValue
public class Ansi
extends java.lang.Object
    The Ansi class wraps an application's stdout and stderr to provide additional console functionality via ANSI escape codes, such as colored output and cursor repositioning. Generally you should use the ansi() method to obtain an instance of this class, which will dynamically determine the appropriate syntax to use for the current environment.

    The ANSI standard is not universally implemented, and behavior will be terminal-specific. For example while most terminals support the standard named colors, support for the more versatile color indexes and 24-bit full-color is less consistent. Cursor movement support is similarly limited on certain terminals. Be sure to test the behavior you expect on any terminals you intend to support.

    Ansi instances are stateful, and are not intended to be persisted, assigned to variables, or used across threads. Instead, chain off the ansi() method directly to compose the behavior you need in a fluent style.

    Note: The "terminating" output methods (out, outln, err, errln) return an Ansi instance so you can continue chaining, but this is simply a convenience; no state from before the terminating method carries over.

    For example: 

      ansi().color(RED).out("Hello ").background(GREEN).out("World");

    does not render "World" in red text, only a green background.

    This class respects the JSR 305 @CheckReturnValue annotation, and you can use Error Prone to help catch incorrect usages that fail to call a terminating method.

    • Method Detail

      • ansi

        public static Ansi ansi()
        Constructs a new Ansi instance configured for the current environment. Generally you should use this method to obtain an Ansi instance.

        Consider importing this method statically: import static com.mwdiamond.fansi.Ansi.ansi;

        You can change this method's behavior per execution with the Java property com.mwdiamond.fansi.ansi. The property is read when this class is first initialized. The following values are currently supported:

        • REAL: the default, makes this method behave like realAnsi().
        • RAW: makes this method behave like rawAnsi().
        • OFF: disables all ANSI escape codes, output is written to stdout/stderr unchanged.
        • CONSOLE:Uses System.console() to detect if the application is running in an interactive shell, and only outputs ANSI escape codes (equivalent to REAL) if so; otherwise escape codes are disabled, like OFF.
        Returns:
        an Ansi instance wrapping System.out and System.err.

      • realAnsi

        public static Ansi realAnsi()
        Constructs a new Ansi instance that always formats strings according to the ANSI standard, even when other environments were detected.
        Returns:
        an Ansi instance wrapping System.out and System.err.

      • rawAnsi

        public static Ansi rawAnsi()
        Constructs a new Ansi instance that formats strings with the character sequences used to create escape codes. Useful for copying or piping into Bash's echo -e.
        Returns:
        an Ansi instance wrapping System.out and System.err.

      • toColorIndex

        public static int toColorIndex(java.awt.Color color)
        Maps a Java Color to a reasonably close color index, for terminals that don't support full colors.
        Parameters:
        color - a Java color
        Returns:
        an approximately equivalent color index

      • color

        public Ansi color(Ansi.Color color,
                  Ansi.Style... styles)
        Sets the color, and optionally the style(s), of the next block of text to display.
        Parameters:
        color - a standard ANSI color
        styles - any additional styles to apply, optional
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • color

        public Ansi color(int colorIndex,
                  Ansi.Style... styles)
        Sets the color, and optionally the style(s), of the next block of text to display.

        Run demo.ColorIndexTable for more color index details.

        Parameters:
        colorIndex - a color index, 0-255
        styles - any additional ANSI styles to apply, optional
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • color

        public Ansi color(java.awt.Color color,
                  Ansi.Style... styles)
        Sets the color, and optionally the style(s), of the next block of text to display.

        Note that 24-bit color support is not universal. You should prefer to use Ansi.Color values where possible.

        Parameters:
        color - a Java color, which will be mapped to RGB integer values
        styles - any additional styles to apply, optional
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • moveCursor

        public Ansi moveCursor(int lines)
        Repositions the cursor up or down a number of lines. Negative values move the cursor up, positive values move it down.
        Parameters:
        lines - a number of lines to move the cursor from its current position
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output
        See Also:
        saveCursor(), restoreCursor()

      • moveCursor

        public Ansi moveCursor(int lines,
                       int columns)
        Move the cursor up or down a number of lines and left or right a number of columns. Negative values are up/left, positive values are down/right.
        Parameters:
        lines - a number of lines to move the cursor from its current position
        columns - a number of columns to move the cursor from its current position
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output
        See Also:
        saveCursor(), restoreCursor()

      • saveCursor

        public void saveCursor()
        Saves the current position of the cursor. Use restoreCursor() to move the cursor back to this position.

        This is not a chainable method, to avoid erroneously calling ansi().saveCursor(); without calling a terminating method (e.g. .out()). The save-cursor code is written to stdout immediately.

        See Also:
        moveCursor(int), restoreCursor()

      • restoreCursor

        public void restoreCursor()
        Restores the cursor to its previously saved position; use in tandem with saveCursor().

        This is not a chainable method, to avoid erroneously calling ansi().restoreCursor(); without calling a terminating method (e.g. .out()). The restore-cursor code is written to stdout immediately.

        See Also:
        moveCursor(int), saveCursor()

      • fixed

        public Ansi fixed(int row,
                  int column)
        Moves the cursor to a fixed position on the screen, where the top left corner is 1, 1. Restores the cursor to its original location afterwards.
        Parameters:
        row - the row to move the cursor to
        column - the column to move the cursor to
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • overwriteThisLine

        public Ansi overwriteThisLine()
        Clears the current line and positions the cursor at the start of the line.
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • overwriteLastLine

        public Ansi overwriteLastLine()
        Clears the current and previous lines and positions the cursor at the start of the previous line.
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • out

        public Ansi out(java.lang.String text,
                java.lang.Object... args)
        Writes text to stdout after piping it and args through String.format().

        Compare to System.out.print()

        Parameters:
        text - the text to write to stdout, wrapped by any previously-specified ANSI codes
        args - arguments to use if text contains printf-style tokens, optional
        Returns:
        a clean Ansi instance, to continue chaining output

        Returns:
        a clean Ansi instance, to continue chaining output

      • delay

        public Ansi delay()
        Helper method to delay output for a short period of time, so users can see the output changing. Useful when overwriting previous lines.

        Note: this calls Thread.sleep() and suppresses any InterruptedException (and restores the thread's interrupted flag) - the application is responsible for handling such interruptions. Do not use this method simply to avoid calling Thread.sleep() yourself - if you really don't want to handle the InterruptedException use Uninterruptibles.sleepUninterruptibly().

        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output

      • delay

        public Ansi delay(long millis)
        Helper method to delay output for a short period of time, so users can see the output changing. Useful when overwriting previous lines.

        Note: this calls Thread.sleep() and suppresses any InterruptedException (and restores the thread's interrupted flag) - the application is responsible for handling such interruptions. Do not use this method simply to avoid calling Thread.sleep() yourself - if you really don't want to handle the InterruptedException use Uninterruptibles.sleepUninterruptibly().

        Parameters:
        millis - a number of milliseconds to delay output
        Returns:
        this Ansi instance, to continue modifying the output
